newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Irish President Robinson not seeking second term.
newsitem.headline: Irish President Robinson not seeking second term.

text.p: Irish president Mary Robinson said on Wednesday that she would not seek a second seven-year term of office.
"It has been a difficult decision for me and I have, with great reluctance, decided not to seek a second term in office," Robinson said in a statement.

"I believe that by the end of this term I will have made my contribution and that the people will give a mandate to a new president with the vision to represent them as we move into the new millennium."
Robinson overcame odds of 1,000-1 in the male-dominated world of Irish politics to win the 1990 presidential election and become the country's first woman head of state.
A lawyer, she injected new vibrancy in the presidency, refusing to follow in the track of earlier incumbents who were rarely seen and never heard.
In her statement, she thanked the people of Ireland for their trust and goodwill during her presidency.
"The unwavering support I have received as President has enabled me to contribute to the development of the office as a resource for all the people, one that is open, inclusive and tolerant."
